intro: Peucedanum ferulaeoides, commonly known as the Persian cow parsley, is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. It is native to Central Asia and is often found in rocky or arid environments. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its flowers are small, white or pale green, and arranged in compound umbels, attracting various pollinators. The roots and leaves have been used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits.
